Criminal Organization Terrorist Designations Pose Research Funding and Partnership Risks

Overview: This executive order empowers federal agencies to designate international criminal syndicates and cartels as foreign terrorist organizations or specially designated global terrorists. Such a designation would make it illegal for U.S. persons, including universities, to provide support or conduct transactions with the named entities. Penalties for noncompliance are severe.

Bottom Line: To mitigate potential disruption to research funding and global engagement, universities must enhance due diligence on foreign financial ties and partnerships, as any link to a designated entity could trigger sanctions.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

Similar sanctions have been used against foreign terrorist groups, but this order is the first to allow designations of criminal enterprises not primarily motivated by political goals. It builds on authorities in the post-9/11 PATRIOT Act and related anti-terrorism financing laws.

Legal Framework:

The order is based on presidential national security powers and statutory sanctions authorities in the Immigration and Nationality Act and International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Implementing sanctions will mainly fall to the Treasury and State Departments.

Higher Education Context:

Higher education institutions have grappled with expanding foreign engagement while managing risks from compromised research partners, espionage, undue foreign government influence, and entanglement with corruption and crime abroad.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Research Grants and Contracts: Federal research awards could be terminated if a designated entity is found to be involved. Private funding from companies or foundations with ties to sanctioned groups could also be jeopardized.

International Partnerships and Programs: Academic partnerships, faculty/student exchanges, and overseas programs could be impacted if a cooperating institution has connections to a designated organization, even if not directly related to the university activities.

Financial Transactions and Services: The order prohibits funds transfers, provision of goods/services, or other transactions with designated entities. This could affect payments to or from foreign campuses, partners, students, or vendors.

Regulatory and Legal Compliance: Universities face substantial civil and criminal penalties for violating sanctions under this order. Compliance requires ongoing monitoring of designated entities and robust internal controls.

Reputational Risk: Any connection to a designated criminal group, even if inadvertent, could significantly damage an institution's public standing and ability to attract students/faculty.

Important Dates:

  • 01/29/2025: Executive order takes effect immediately upon signing
  • 04/29/2025: Estimated 90 days for agencies to make initial designations under the order

Affected Departments:

Research Administration and Sponsored Projects, Global Partnerships and International Affairs, General Counsel and Compliance, Government Affairs and University Relations, Student and Faculty International Recruitment/Mobility

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

Must avoid providing funds, goods, services, or other support to designated criminal groups. Requires checking sanctions lists, understanding ownership/control of foreign partners, and strict internal payment controls.

Technical Analysis:

The most difficult aspect is mapping complex networks of front companies, affiliates, and proxies to determine if a foreign partner is actually tied to a designated group. Requires specialized investigation tools and data sources.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

Affects research, international programs, enrollment, advancement/development, finance, and legal. Requires coordinated management and oversight via standing compliance committee or task force.

Risk Analysis:

Financial and legal risks of noncompliance are high - similar violations have drawn millions in penalties. Equally severe are risks to reputation, research integrity, and institutional autonomy if seen as enabling crime/corruption.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Proactive, well-resourced compliance efforts will be a competitive advantage, facilitating more nimble global engagement. Under-prepared institutions risk being cut off from critical international opportunities.

Long-term Vision:

Effective management of such geopolitical regulatory risks will be an increasingly important strategic differentiator as the global education and research landscape grows more complex and volatile.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Universities, individually and via associations, should provide feedback to agencies on implementation to ensure regulations are clear and account for higher education needs like academic freedom and international collaboration.

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes - the severe consequences of noncompliance and reputational fallout of any links to criminal networks require universities to act quickly to assess and mitigate risks from foreign funding and partnerships.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Issue university-wide guidance on the order and its general implications
  • Begin comprehensive review of all foreign research funding for potential concerns
  • Identify and risk-assess all international institutional partnerships and programs
  • Consult external legal experts and peer institutions on best compliance practices

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Strengthen internal vetting procedures and due diligence for foreign engagements
  • Conduct scenario planning for possible loss of international funding/partnerships
  • Train staff on terrorist financing regulations and how to spot warning signs

Long-term Considerations:

  • Continually monitor government lists of sanctioned groups for relevant additions
  • Engage strategically with policymakers to ensure fair implementation for universities
  • Consider broader geopolitical and security trends in evaluating foreign opportunities

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Will require dedicated compliance staff with expertise in sanctions law and criminal finance. May necessitate new senior official (e.g. Chief Global Risk Officer).

Budget: Substantial investments needed in enhanced due diligence, outside counsel, new staff, and compliance technology/data. Reduced revenue also possible from lost international funding.

Technology: Sanctions screening and transaction monitoring software, foreign corporate registries, international media databases, and other specialized information sources.

External Expertise: Outside law firms and consultants with deep experience in sanctions compliance and cross-border education/research partnerships.
